title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Beth had 150 students in her 10th-grade class.  The following year 30 more students join.  In her final year, 15 students left.  How many students did Beth have in her class at the end of her final year?

Beth starts out with 150 students and 30 more join so she is at 150+30 = <<150+30=180>>180 students
She started with 180 students and 15 left, leaving her with 180-15 = <<180-15=165>>165 students. Answer: \boxed{165}.


Question: Beth had 150 students in her 10th-grade class.  The following year 30 more students join.  In her final year, 15 students left.  How many students did Beth have in her class at the end of her final year?

Beth had 150+30 = <<150+30=180>>180 students in her class in the 11th grade.
Beth had 180-15 = <<180-15=165>>165 students in her class at the end of her 12th grade. Answer: \boxed{165}.


Question: Beth had 150 students in her 10th-grade class.  The following year 30 more students join.  In her final year, 15 students left.  How many students did Beth have in her class at the end of her final year?

Beth had 150+30=<<150+30=180>>180 students in her 11th-grade class.
Beth had 180-15=<<180-15=165>>165 students in her final year. Answer: \boxed{165}.


Question: Beth had 150 students in her 10th-grade class.  The following year 30 more students join.  In her final year, 15 students left.  How many students did Beth have in her class at the end of her final year?

The next year Beth had 150 + 30 students = <<150+30=180>>180 students.
Until the end of the year 15 students left, so she had 180 - 15 = <<180-15=165>>165 students. Answer: \boxed{165}.


Question: Beth had 150 students in her 10th-grade class.  The following year 30 more students join.  In her final year, 15 students left.  How many students did Beth have in her class at the end of her final year?

Beth had 150 students in 10th grade. In the following year, 30 more students join her class so she has 150 + 30 = <<150+30=180>>180 students.
In her final year, 15 students left her class so she had 180 - 15 = <<180-15=165>>165 students. Answer: \boxed{165}.


Question: Beth had 150 students in her 10th-grade class.  The following year 30 more students join.  In her final year, 15 students left.  How many students did Beth have in her class at the end of her final year?
text:
Beth started with 150 students in her 10th-grade class. In the following year, 30 more students join her class, so she had 150 + 30 = <<150+30=180>>180 students in her 11th-grade class.
In her final year, 15 students left her class, leaving her with 180 - 15 = <<180-15=165>>165 students. Answer: \boxed{165}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Harper drinks a 1/2 bottle of mineral water per day.  She buys the mineral water by the case at a big box store.  They come 24 bottles to a case and are currently on sale for $12.00.  If she wants to buy enough cases to last her 240 days, how much will she spend?

Harper drinks 1/2 a bottle of mineral water per day and there are 24 bottles of mineral water per case so a case will last 24/.5 = <<24/.5=48>>48 days
She wants to buy enough for 240 days and a case will last her 48 days so she needs 240/48 = <<240/48=5>>5 cases
The cases are on sale for $12.00 each and she needs 5 cases so they will cost her 12*5 = $<<12*5=60.00>>60.00. Answer: \boxed{60}.


Question: Harper drinks a 1/2 bottle of mineral water per day.  She buys the mineral water by the case at a big box store.  They come 24 bottles to a case and are currently on sale for $12.00.  If she wants to buy enough cases to last her 240 days, how much will she spend?

She drinks 1/2 a bottle of water per day and there are 24 bottles in a case so a case lasts her 24/.5 = <<24/.5=48>>48 days
She needs enough cases for 240 days and 1 case lasts 48 days so she needs 240/48 = <<240/48=5>>5 cases
The cases are on sale for $12.00 and she needs 5 cases so she will spend 12*5 = $<<12*5=60.00>>60.00. Answer: \boxed{60}.


Question: Harper drinks a 1/2 bottle of mineral water per day.  She buys the mineral water by the case at a big box store.  They come 24 bottles to a case and are currently on sale for $12.00.  If she wants to buy enough cases to last her 240 days, how much will she spend?

Harper drinks 1/2 bottle of water per day and she wants enough to last her 240 days so she needs 1/2*240 = <<1/2*240=120>>120 bottles
The mineral water comes 24 bottles to a case and she needs 120 bottles so she needs to buy 120/24 = <<120/24=5>>5 cases
The cases are on sale for $12.00 and she needs 5 cases so that comes to 12*5 = $<<12*5=60.00>>60.00. Answer: \boxed{60}.


Question: Harper drinks a 1/2 bottle of mineral water per day.  She buys the mineral water by the case at a big box store.  They come 24 bottles to a case and are currently on sale for $12.00.  If she wants to buy enough cases to last her 240 days, how much will she spend?

She drinks 1/2 bottle of water per day and she wants enough to last 240 days so she needs .5*240 = <<1/2*240=120>>120 bottles
They come 24 to a case and she needs 120 bottles so that's 120/24 = <<120/24=5>>5 cases of water
The cases cost $12.00 and she needs 5 cases so that will cost her 12*5 = $<<12*5=60.00>>60.00. Answer: \boxed{60}.


Question: Harper drinks a 1/2 bottle of mineral water per day.  She buys the mineral water by the case at a big box store.  They come 24 bottles to a case and are currently on sale for $12.00.  If she wants to buy enough cases to last her 240 days, how much will she spend?

Harper drinks 1/2 bottle of mineral water per day and she wants enough for 240 days so she needs 1/2*240 = <<1/2*240=120>>120 bottles of mineral water
The mineral water is sold 24 bottles per case and she needs 120 bottles so she needs 120/24 = <<120/24=5>>5 cases of mineral water
Each case of mineral water is on sale for $12.00 and she needs 5 cases so she will spend 12*5 = $<<12*5=60.00>>60.00. Answer: \boxed{60}.


Question: Harper drinks a 1/2 bottle of mineral water per day.  She buys the mineral water by the case at a big box store.  They come 24 bottles to a case and are currently on sale for $12.00.  If she wants to buy enough cases to last her 240 days, how much will she spend?
text:
Harper drinks 1/2 bottle of mineral water per day and she wants enough for 240 days. This means she needs 1/2 * 240 = 120 bottles of mineral water. Each case at the store contains 24 bottles, so she needs 120/24 = 5 cases of mineral water. 
Since each case is on sale for $12.00, Harper will spend 12 * 5 = $60.00. 
Answer: \boxed{60}.

title:

Examples:
    
Question: Estevan has 24 blankets. One-third of the blankets have polka-dots. For his birthday, his mother gives him 2 more polka-dot print blankets. How many polka-dot blankets does Estevan have in total?

Estevan has 24/3 = <<24/3=8>>8 polka-dot print blankets.
After his mother gives him 2 more polka-dot blankets, he has a total of 8 + 2 = <<8+2=10>>10 polka-dot blankets. Answer: \boxed{10}.

One-third of the blankets Estevan has is (1/3)*24 = <<(1/3)*24=8>>8 blankets.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Lorenzo put three full cans of thumbtacks into his pocket and went off to work at the corkboard factory. It was Lorenzo's job, as head of quality control, to test every cork board for its ability to hold thumbtacks.  He placed one thumbtack from each of the three cans of thumbtacks into every board tested.  At the end of the day, he had tested 120 boards and had 30 tacks remaining in each of the three cans.  What was the total combined number of thumbtacks from the three full cans?

Lorenzo tested 120 boards and used 3 thumbtacks from each board, which means he used a total of 120 * 3 = <<120*3=360>>360 thumbtacks.
At the end of the day, he had 30 tacks remaining in each can, so he started the day with 360 + 30 + 30 + 30 = <<360+30+30+30=450>>450 thumbtacks. Answer: \boxed{450}.


Question: Lorenzo put three full cans of thumbtacks into his pocket and went off to work at the corkboard factory. It was Lorenzo's job, as head of quality control, to test every cork board for its ability to hold thumbtacks.  He placed one thumbtack from each of the three cans of thumbtacks into every board tested.  At the end of the day, he had tested 120 boards and had 30 tacks remaining in each of the three cans.  What was the total combined number of thumbtacks from the three full cans?

Lorenzo tested 120 boards, with 3 thumbtacks in each board, for a total of 120*3=<<120*3=360>>360 thumbtacks.
Lorenzo had 30 thumbtacks remaining in each of the 3 cans, for a total of 3*30=<<3*30=90>>90 thumbtacks remaining.
The total combined number of thumbtacks from the three full cans is 360+90=<<360+90=450>>450. Answer: \boxed{450}.


Question: Lorenzo put three full cans of thumbtacks into his pocket and went off to work at the corkboard factory. It was Lorenzo's job, as head of quality control, to test every cork board for its ability to hold thumbtacks.  He placed one thumbtack from each of the three cans of thumbtacks into every board tested.  At the end of the day, he had tested 120 boards and had 30 tacks remaining in each of the three cans.  What was the total combined number of thumbtacks from the three full cans?

At the end of the day, Lorenzo had 30 tacks remaining in each of the three cans, for a total of 3*30=<<30*3=90>>90 thumbtacks.
Each board uses 3 thumbtacks, so 120 boards were tested, and thus, 120*3=<<120*3=360>>360 thumbtacks were used.
Thus, Lorenzo started with a total of 360+90=<<360+90=450>>450 thumbtacks from the three full cans. Answer: \boxed{450}.


Question: Lorenzo put three full cans of thumbtacks into his pocket and went off to work at the corkboard factory. It was Lorenzo's job, as head of quality control, to test every cork board for its ability to hold thumbtacks.  He placed one thumbtack from each of the three cans of thumbtacks into every board tested.  At the end of the day, he had tested 120 boards and had 30 tacks remaining in each of the three cans.  What was the total combined number of thumbtacks from the three full cans?

Lorenzo used 3 tacks for each of the 120 boards he tested so he used 3*120 = <<3*120=360>>360 thumbtacks
The three cans only had 30 tacks left in each, a total of 3*30 = <<3*30=90>>90 thumbtacks
The total number of thumbtacks from the three full cans is 360+90 = <<360+90=450>>450 thumbtacks. Answer: \boxed{450}.


Question: Wyatt's mother gave him $74 to go to the store. Wyatt bought 5 loaves of bread and 4 cartons of orange juice. Each loaf of bread cost $5 and each carton of orange juice cost $2. How much money does Wyatt have left?

The total cost of the bread is 5 × $5 = $<<5*5=25>>25.
The total cost of the orange juice is 4 × $2 = $<<4*2=8>>8.
The total cost of the items is $25 + $8 = $<<25+8=33>>33.
Wyatt has $74 − $33 = $<<74-33=41>>41 left. Answer: \boxed{41}.


Question: Lorenzo put three full cans of thumbtacks into his pocket and went off to work at the corkboard factory. It was Lorenzo's job, as head of quality control, to test every cork board for its ability to hold thumbtacks.  He placed one thumbtack from each of the three cans of thumbtacks into every board tested.  At the end of the day, he had tested 120 boards and had 30 tacks remaining in each of the three cans.  What was the total combined number of thumbtacks from the three full cans?
text:
Lorenzo tested 120 boards and placed 3 thumbtacks in each board, so he used a total of 120 * 3 = <<120*3=360>>360 thumbtacks.
At the end of the day, he had 30 thumbtacks remaining in each can, so he started with 360 + 30 + 30 + 30 = <<360+30+30+30=450>>450 thumbtacks from the three full cans. Answer: \boxed{450}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Janice adds 2 tablespoons of koolaid power and 16 tablespoons of water to a jug. She leaves it out long enough for 4 tablespoons of water to evaporate. Then she quadruples the amount of water in the jug. What percentage of the liquid in the jug is koolaid powder?

Initially, Janice has 16 - 4 = <<16-4=12>>12 tablespoons of water in the jug.
After quadrupling the water amount, she has 12 * 4 = <<12*4=48>>48 tablespoons of water in the jug.
The total amount of liquid in the jug is 48 + 2 = <<48+2=50>>50 tablespoons.
So, the percentage of koolaid powder in the liquid is (2/50) * 100% = 4%. Answer: \boxed{4}.


Question: Janice gave all three dozens of pebbles from her trip to her friends. Each of her friends got 4 pebbles. How many friends received pebbles?

All three dozens are equal to 12 x 3 = <<12*3=36>>36.
Therefore, Janice's friends are 36/4 = <<36/4=9>>9. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: Janice gave all three dozens of pebbles from her trip to her friends. Each of her friends got 4 pebbles. How many friends received pebbles?

Three dozens of pebbles is equal to 3 x 12 = <<3*12=36>>36 pebbles.
There were 36/4 = <<36/4=9>>9 friends who received pebbles. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: When Betty makes cheesecake, she sweetens it with a ratio of one part sugar to four parts cream cheese, and she flavors it with one teaspoon of vanilla for every two cups of cream cheese. For every one teaspoon of vanilla, she uses two eggs. She used two cups of sugar in her latest cheesecake. How many eggs did she use?

Since Betty uses a ratio of 1 part sugar to 4 parts cream cheese, and she used 2 cups of sugar, she used 2*4=<<2*4=8>>8 cups of cream cheese.
Since for every 1 teaspoon of vanilla, she uses 2 eggs, for 8 cups of cream cheese, Betty used 8/2=4 teaspoons of vanilla.
So, Betty used 4*2=<<4*2=8>>8 eggs. Answer: \boxed{8}.


Question: When Betty makes cheesecake, she sweetens it with a ratio of one part sugar to four parts cream cheese, and she flavors it with one teaspoon of vanilla for every two cups of cream cheese. For every one teaspoon of vanilla, she uses two eggs. She used two cups of sugar in her latest cheesecake. How many eggs did she use?

First find the number of cups of cream cheese Betty used: 2 cups sugar * 4 parts cream cheese / 1 part sugar = <<2*4=8>>8 cups cream cheese
Then divide that amount by the amount of cream cheese per teaspoon of vanilla to find how many teaspoons of vanilla she used: 8 cups cream cheese / 2 cups cream cheese/teaspoon vanilla = <<8/2=4>>4 teaspoons vanilla
Then multiply the number of teaspoons of vanilla by the ratio of eggs per teaspoon to find the number of eggs: 4 teaspoons * 2 eggs/teaspoon = <<4*2=8>>8 eggs. Answer: \boxed{8}.


Question: Janice adds 2 tablespoons of koolaid power and 16 tablespoons of water to a jug. She leaves it out long enough for 4 tablespoons of water to evaporate. Then she quadruples the amount of water in the jug. What percentage of the liquid in the jug is koolaid powder?
text:
Initially, Janice has 16 - 4 = <<16-4=12>>12 tablespoons of water in the jug.
After quadrupling the water amount, she has 12 * 4 = <<12*4=48>>48 tablespoons of water in the jug.
The total amount of liquid in the jug is 48 + 2 = <<48+2=50>>50 tablespoons.
So, the percentage of koolaid powder in the liquid is (2/50) * 100% = 4%. Answer: \boxed{4}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Rory has 30 more jellybeans than her sister Gigi who has 15 jellybeans.  Lorelai has already eaten three times the number of jellybeans that both girls have.  How many jellybeans has Lorelai eaten?

Rory has 30 more jellybeans than Gigi who has 15 jellybeans so Rory has 30+15 = <<30+15=45>>45 jellybeans
If Gigi has 15 jellybeans and Rory has 45 jellybeans then all together the girls have 15+45 = <<15+45=60>>60 jellybeans
Lorelai has already eaten three times the number of jellybeans that both girls have, triple their total of 60 jellybeans to get 3*60 = <<3*60=180>>180 jellybeans. Answer: \boxed{180}.


Question: Rory has 30 more jellybeans than her sister Gigi who has 15 jellybeans.  Lorelai has already eaten three times the number of jellybeans that both girls have.  How many jellybeans has Lorelai eaten?

Rory has 15+30 = <<15+30=45>>45 jellybeans.
Together, Rory and Gigi have 45+15 = <<45+15=60>>60 jelly beans
Lorelai has eaten 60 x 3 = <<60*3=180>>180 jellybeans. Answer: \boxed{180}.


Question: Rory has 30 more jellybeans than her sister Gigi who has 15 jellybeans.  Lorelai has already eaten three times the number of jellybeans that both girls have.  How many jellybeans has Lorelai eaten?

Rory has 30 more jellybeans than her sister Gigi who has 15 jellybeans, so Rory has 30+15 = <<30+15=45>>45 jellybeans
Combined the two sisters have 45+15 = <<45+15=60>>60 jellybeans
Lorelai has already eaten three times that number which is 60*3 = <<60*3=180>>180 jellybeans. Answer: \boxed{180}.


Question: Rory has 30 more jellybeans than her sister Gigi who has 15 jellybeans.  Lorelai has already eaten three times the number of jellybeans that both girls have.  How many jellybeans has Lorelai eaten?

Rory has 30 more jellybeans than Gigi who has 15 jellybeans, so Rory has 30+15=<<30+15=45>>45 jellybeans.
At the current time Rory and Gigi have 45+15=<<45+15=60>>60 jellybeans.
Lorelai has already eaten three times the number of jellybeans that both girls have, so Lorelai has eaten 60*3=<<60*3=180>>180 jellybeans. Answer: \boxed{180}.


Question: Caleb has 3 dozen jellybeans.  Sophie has half as many jellybeans as Caleb.  How many jellybeans do they have in total?

Since 1 dozen is equal to 12 jellybeans then Caleb has 3*12 = <<3*12=36>>36 jellybeans
Sophie has 36/2 = <<36/2=18>>18 jellybeans.
Together, they have 36+18=<<36+18=54>>54 jellybeans. Answer: \boxed{54}.


Question: Rory has 30 more jellybeans than her sister Gigi who has 15 jellybeans.  Lorelai has already eaten three times the number of jellybeans that both girls have.  How many jellybeans has Lorelai eaten?
text:
Rory has 30 more jellybeans than her sister Gigi who has 15 jellybeans, so Rory has 30+15 = <<30+15=45>>45 jellybeans.
Combined, Rory and Gigi have 45+15 = <<45+15=60>>60 jellybeans.
Lorelai has already eaten three times the number of jellybeans that both girls have, so Lorelai has eaten 60*3 = <<60*3=180>>180 jellybeans. Answer: \boxed{180}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Out of the 200 cookies that Javier baked from the recipe he learned online, his wife took 30%, and his daughter took 40 from the remaining cookies. If he ate half of the remaining cookies, how many cookies did they not eat?

Javier's wife took 30/100*200 = <<30/100*200=60>>60 cookies.
After Javier's wife took 60 cookies, the total number of cookies remaining was 200-60 = <<200-60=140>>140 cookies.
His daughter took 40 cookies from the remaining 140, leaving 140-40 = <<140-40=100>>100 cookies.
Since Javier ate half of the remaining 100, they did not eat 1/2*100 = <<1/2*100=50>>50 cookies. Answer: \boxed{50}.


Question: Out of the 200 cookies that Javier baked from the recipe he learned online, his wife took 30%, and his daughter took 40 from the remaining cookies. If he ate half of the remaining cookies, how many cookies did they not eat?

Javier's wife took 30/100*200 = <<30/100*200=60>>60 cookies.
The total number of cookies that were not eaten by Javier's wife is 200-60 = <<200-60=140>>140
His daughter took 40 cookies so he had 140-40 = <<140-40=100>>100 cookies remaining.
If he ate half of the remaining cookies, he ate 100/2 = <<100/2=50>>50 cookies
The total number of cookies that were not eaten by Javier and his family is 100-50 = <<100-50=50>>50. Answer: \boxed{50}.


Question: Out of the 200 cookies that Javier baked from the recipe he learned online, his wife took 30%, and his daughter took 40 from the remaining cookies. If he ate half of the remaining cookies, how many cookies did they not eat?

Javier's wife took 30/100*200 = <<30/100*200=60>>60 cookies
The number of cookies that remained is 200-60 = <<200-60=140>>140
The number of cookies that his daughter took is 40
The number of cookies that remained after his daughter took is 140-40 = <<140-40=100>>100
Javier ate 1/2*100 = <<1/2*100=50>>50 cookies reducing the number to 100-50 = <<100-50=50>>50. Answer: \boxed{50}.


Question: Out of the 200 cookies that Javier baked from the recipe he learned online, his wife took 30%, and his daughter took 40 from the remaining cookies. If he ate half of the remaining cookies, how many cookies did they not eat?

Javier's wife ate 30/100*200 = <<30/100*200=60>>60 of the cookies.
So there were 200-60 = <<200-60=140>>140 cookies remaining.
If Javier's daughter also took some cookies, they were left with 140-40 = <<140-40=100>>100 cookies after the daughter took some.
Then Javier took half of the remaining number of cookies, which is 1/2*100 = <<1/2*100=50>>50 cookies.
The total cookies that were not eaten are 100-50= <<100-50=50>>50. Answer: \boxed{50}.


Question: Cristian has 50 more black cookies in his cookie jar than white cookies. He eats half of the black cookies and 3/4 of the white cookies. If he initially had 80 white cookies, how many cookies are remaining within the cookie jar altogether?

If Cristian had 80 white cookies and eats 3/4 of them, he ate 3/4*80 = <<3/4*80=60>>60 white cookies.
Cristian remains with 80-60 = <<80-60=20>>20 white cookies.
Cristian also had 50 more black cookies in the jar initially than white cookies, a total of 80+50 = <<50+80=130>>130 black cookies.
When he eats half of the black cookies, the number of black cookies reduces to 1/2*130 = <<1/2*130=65>>65 black cookies.
The total number of cookies remaining in the jar altogether is 65+20 = <<65+20=85>>85. Answer: \boxed{85}.


Question: Out of the 200 cookies that Javier baked from the recipe he learned online, his wife took 30%, and his daughter took 40 from the remaining cookies. If he ate half of the remaining cookies, how many cookies did they not eat?
text:
Javier's wife took 30/100*200 = <<30/100*200=60>>60 cookies.
The remaining number of cookies is 200-60 = <<200-60=140>>140.
His daughter took 40 cookies from the remaining cookies.
The remaining number of cookies after his daughter took is 140-40 = <<140-40=100>>100.
Javier ate half of the remaining cookies, which is 1/2*100 = <<1/2*100=50>>50 cookies.
Therefore, they did not eat 50 cookies. Answer: \boxed{50}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Jeremy buys 30 watermelons. He eats 3 watermelons per week. Each week he gives 2 to his dad. How many weeks will the watermelons last?

Jeremy eats 3 watermelons per week + Jeremy gives away 2 watermelons per week = <<3+2=5>>5 per week.
Therefore, 30 watermelons / 5 watermelons per week = <<30/5=6>>6 weeks. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: Jeremy buys 30 watermelons. He eats 3 watermelons per week. Each week he gives 2 to his dad. How many weeks will the watermelons last?

Jeremy eats 3 watermelons per week and gives away 2, so he uses 3+2 = <<3+2=5>>5 watermelons per week.
Jeremy has 30 watermelons and uses 5 per week so the watermelons will last for 30/5 = <<30/5=6>>6 weeks. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: Jeremy buys 30 watermelons. He eats 3 watermelons per week. Each week he gives 2 to his dad. How many weeks will the watermelons last?

Each week he consumes 3 + 2 = <<3+2=5>>5 watermelons
The watermelons will last (30/5)= <<30/5=6>>6 weeks. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: Jeremy buys 30 watermelons. He eats 3 watermelons per week. Each week he gives 2 to his dad. How many weeks will the watermelons last?

Each week Jeremy eats 3 watermelons + gives 2 to his dad = <<3+2=5>>5 watermelons.
So, 30 watermelons / 5 watermelons per week = <<30/5=6>>6 weeks. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: Jeremy buys 3 bags of chips for a party. Stacy and Emily also buy chips for the party. If they need 10 bags of chips total, and Stacy buys 4 bags, how many bags of chips should Emily buy?

Jeremy buys 3, and Stacy buys 4, so they have 3 + 4 = <<3+4=7>>7 bags
Emily should buy 10 - 7 = <<10-7=3>>3 bags. Answer: \boxed{3}.


Question: Jeremy buys 30 watermelons. He eats 3 watermelons per week. Each week he gives 2 to his dad. How many weeks will the watermelons last?
text:
Jeremy eats 3 watermelons per week and gives away 2, so he consumes 3 + 2 = <<3+2=5>>5 watermelons per week.
Therefore, the watermelons will last for 30/5 = <<30/5=6>>6 weeks. Answer: \boxed{6}.

Examples:
    
Question: A hot dog stand sells 10 hot dogs every hour, each one selling for $2.  How many hours does the stand need to run to make $200 in sales?

The stand makes 10 hot dogs every hour for $2 each so it makes 10*2 = $<<10*2=20>>20 per hour
To make $200 the stand needs to run for 200/20 = <<200/20=10>>10 hours. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: A hot dog stand sells 10 hot dogs every hour, each one selling for $2.  How many hours does the stand need to run to make $200 in sales?

Each hour the stand makes 10 hot dogs * $2 = $<<10*2=20>>20.
To reach $200 in sales, the stand needs to run $200 / $20 = <<200/20=10>>10 hours. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: A hot dog stand sells 10 hot dogs every hour, each one selling for $2.  How many hours does the stand need to run to make $200 in sales?

The stand makes $2 per hot dog * 10 hot dogs per hour = $<<2*10=20>>20 per hour.
Thus, the stand needs to run for $200 / $20 per hour = <<200/20=10>>10 hours. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: A hot dog stand sells 10 hot dogs every hour, each one selling for $2.  How many hours does the stand need to run to make $200 in sales?

A hot dog stand makes 10*2=<<10*2=20>>20 dollars an hour.
The stand needs to run for 200/20=<<200/20=10>>10 hours to make 200 dollars. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: A hot dog stand sells 10 hot dogs every hour, each one selling for $2.  How many hours does the stand need to run to make $200 in sales?

The hot dog stand makes $20 every hour because 10 x 2 = <<10*2=20>>20
The stand needs to run for 10 hours because 200 / 20 = <<200/20=10>>10. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: A hot dog stand sells 10 hot dogs every hour, each one selling for $2.  How many hours does the stand need to run to make $200 in sales?
text: The stand sells 10 hot dogs every hour, each for $2, so it makes $10 \times $2 = $<<10*2=20>>20 per hour. To make $200 in sales, the stand needs to run for $200/$20 = <<200/20=10>>10 hours. Answer: \boxed{10}.
